description.text:
As an Octoprint server, I am using an Orange PI Zero which has got some advantages over a regular PI:

  • It's small (about 4.5 x 4.5 cm)
  • It's got WiFi
  • It's dirt cheap (9$+PP)
    I wanted to have a case which incorporated the A8's electronics, Octoprint server, a relay board and an external USB connector for a webcam (I like things tidy on the outside).
    Since the OrangePI Zero does only have one USB (two more are on a daughterboard which I can't use since I have developed a board for connecting filament sensor and capacitive Z sensor), I had to incorporate a tiny USB hub as well.

title: Honda Brake or Clutch Pedal Stopper Pad (Civic Accord CRX Prelude)

description.text:
If your Honda vehicle brake lights won't turn off, and there are some weird broken plastic pieces laying on your floorboard near your pedals, then this is probably what you need. I hope this helps someone out.

This part should fit a wide number of model years of Honda vehicles and should be a direct replacement for Honda part 46505-SA5-000 and the Dorman 74015 (only the white replacement part that is included in that Dorman kit).

Based on the original from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:924433
I really appreciate MS3FGX for getting me started on my own attempt. Instead of using OpenSCAD, I used Autodesk 123D since I'm familiar with it (I'm still relatively new to 3D printing and haven't gotten my feet wet with OpenSCAD yet). I unfortunately had a rough time inserting MS3FGX's part after printing and had to use a file around the widest part of the 'cone' diameter several times before I could forcefully insert it into the hole in the pedal arm (maybe just the result of my 3D printer's tolerances). I also took the small edge of a flat jewelers file and filed a small indentation around the base of the shaft (similar to the original part) which I'm confident will help keep it from falling out over the long haul. This version has the indentation included.

My hope is that this part is virtually an exact duplicate of the original OEM part that was in my 1994 Honda. I'll just admit right now that I never printed it since I had already modified MS3FGX's part to fit my car. I'm just posting this version as an afterthought to help out anyone else who wants one a little closer to the original OEM part that came with their vehicle. I used the 3 broken pieces laying on my floorboard to take these measurements from (see my measurements in the included image). The center shaft was not broken, so I was able to get good measurements from it with calipers. The 'head' was in two pieces, but I was also able to get good measurements from those pieces as well. Anyone printing this may want to take into account the tolerances inherent with their 3D printer to ensure the part doesn't get much bigger. It may make it difficult to insert into the pedal arm and may require some slight sanding/filing to correct. As MS3FGX mentioned in his original comments, you'll want to ensure the infill is sufficient to lend the part enough strength to hold up under pedal punishment (=> 30% ?). What I did was use my slicer (Cura) to increase the 'bottom layer thickness' until there was no infill whatsoever in the head of the part which is what gets sandwiched between the switch and the brake pedal arm.

description.text:
Japanese fidget rolling / spinning / wobbling toy.

This is a one-piece no-support no-assembly print at 100% infill. There are solid endcaps for weighting and the main body is hollow (see the cut-away view).

The OpenSCAD code is highly customizable. Among many size adjustments, you can also add holes where you can pause print and insert weights. Code uses and includes my Bezier library.

I printed in PLA (higher density than ABS) and superglued rubber circles cut from an old bicycle inner-tube on the ends.

Video of it in action.

Update 1: You can now print versions with polygonal sides. Depending on how you look at it, this makes the toy either more challenging or disappointing. It's just a lot harder to get to roll neatly with polygonal sides. Four sides is very difficult. But feel free to change the number of sides in the Customizer (it has 40 for a circle).

Update 2: No longer uses paths library.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0a with Repetier

author: Demonic69

description.text:
This 3D Printer control panel combines a USB port and an LED Lighting Dimmer which can be mounted on any 2020 extrusion. I mounted mine on the front of my printer but it will work on the side or back as well. The USB port uses an extension cable that plugs into the controller. The other end screws to this panel. This panel makes it more convenient to connect your printer by placing the connector on the perimeter.

I used this USB extension cable which has a 90 degree bend on the male end and a panel mount connector on the female end:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LRZ8GK2
This is the LED Dimmer I used:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HTZZF9A
My LED Dimmer Thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2009479
My HyperCube:
http://www.thingiverse.com/make:272257

Featured In These YouTube Videos:

  • Four in series (3.6T to one) - https://youtu.be/nvRgVUEBfp0
    • Torque testing and back-driving test - https://youtu.be/tgJUiEC9_-A
    • Three in series (2.6 Billion to 1) and gear ratio calculation - https://youtu.be/sNG63sWiV9k
    • Two In series(1.9M to 1) and explanation - https://youtu.be/VnWY0r1r9lQ
Torque Capabilities

Please know that i designed this gearbox for a demonstration model so that it would be easy for everyone to understand how a differential planetary works, for that reason i omitted the 3rd module that increases the torque capabilities.
Because of that, this gearbox cannot handle much load and it will start to skip teeth at around 3.5FT-LBS. There is more info on this in the youtube videos.

How This Works

  • 1,379 Turns of the input sun gear will result in ring gear #2 making one full rotation.
    These are designed to be able to mount them in series on the channel, or drive them with the included stepper motor mount. You will need to scale the channel longer if you want to use two gearboxes and the stepper motor mount on the same channel, but keep in mind it is very boring to watch the second gearbox rotate, as it is very slow.
  • This gearbox can not be back-driven, every piece of plastic on it will snap before you get the input to turn.

Gearing Information:

  • The gear ratio of two of these in series is 1,901,641:1
  • Three in series 2.6 Billion :1

Gears Used

Helix angle 30deg
Pressure Angle 20deg

  • Planetary Gearset #1 (Input End) Tooth Module = 1

    • Sun = 16T
    • Planets = 17T
    • Ring = 50T
  • Planetary Gearset #2 (Output End) Tooth Module = .846
    • Sun = 19T
    • Planets = 20T
    • Ring = 59T

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??

  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link:http://a360.co/2izCe0i

  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, I'll link to them and possible create a collection for all of them!
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

title: Noise Damper – Schalldämpfer für MK8 Extruderlüfter

description.text:
The airflow management of the Geeetech Prusa i3x is a bit special. If you had to design a siren you would have placed blocking and open areas alternately in just the same way is has been done here. The fan blades almost touch the cooling ribs and can’t blow freely but instead compress the air when blocked and release it when there is enough space. This makes the already very loud Geeetech fans even noisier. To get rid of the siren effect I printed distance rings that keep the fan blades from cutting the air loudly at the cooling ribs. You just need two 3-mm-screws that are 4 to 5 mm longer now.

By the way: when you have disassembled the extruder unit you could take the chance and get rid of the loud original fan in favour of a better designed one.

STL Boolean

I tried using Inventor to convert the mesh to solid, no joy. Even tried it in Fusion 360. Messed around with boolean in MeshMixer, but it wasn't clean.

In the end, this is what worked best:

I'm not much of a surface editor, so I imported the STL in Inventor 2017 as a mesh, created the inserts as hole plugs as a solid to line up with the mesh, then deleted the mesh, exported just the solid as a STL, then did a simple difference Boolean of the original STL file and the exported holes in openSCAD.

The hole plugs have a step for the head, and is tapered 2° per the drawing.

This is an enclosure for a micro-sized 15mm x 11mm x 3.5mm cell phone speaker, to be used inside my RC Transmitter. The speaker I am using is Knowles 2403-260-00001, available from Digikey as well as other sources. The box provides the airspace required for the small speaker to make a big sound.

This is a generic customizable knob with a lot of options (and not a lot of error checking so don't change too much at once). Multiple types of shafts can be accommodated including: circle, circle with internal or external keyway, D (partial circle), and any polygon (triangle, square, etc.). There is a test option to generate a simple disc with the specified hole/shaft pattern and mark angle for test fitting prior to printing the full model. The "standard" stl is based on a knob for an old heater that broke.

Edited .scad file to be more user friendly especially with the customizer and decreased the default $fn to 30 for quicker rendering, but you can always increase it if you want. Also, the rounded top feature was turned off by default to speed rendering.

This is a simple bug antennae headband that I made for our four-year-old to go along with her butterfly wings.

Print in ABS for flexibility, and then glue the antennae into their holders on the headband (ABS juice is ideal). You may need to adjust the tolerance on the holders. No supports needed.

This is highly customizable: size, aspect ratio, how large the teeth on the headband are, how long the stalks are, how big the rounded tips are, are the stalk tips flat or ball (if ball, you'll have to glue the two halves together, unless you want slightly-more-than-half balls), etc.

Code uses and bundles my Bezier library.

For the Cam mount:
Servo is a standard 9g Micro Server. The base can be secured with screws or ties. I created slots and guides to keep the ties in place. i use 2 ties with double sided tape. The camera should overhang the front of your quad so it can fully tilt downwards.

Please note this has been designed with the use of 2mm wide ties in mind. The regular 2.5 mm ties might be a little tight.

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 monolith frame plus new braces and all printer parts refined

description.text:
This is a corner bracket for the Anet A8. It was taken directly from the .dxf files of the Anet A8 monolith frame (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2094209 - many thanks for uploading this and taking the time to design it.) I extruded it in Solidworks to be the same thickness as the acrylic stock frame.

It has a slightly smaller profile than the original bracket but fits perfectly with the stock frame, no changes needed. I used this to replace my broken stock bracket.

This works on both left and right sides of the original frame.

Update I uploaded the wrong .stl file that was 5mm thick instead of 8mm thick - the correct file is now available to download.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.32

Infill:

30% - not critical

Notes:

For infill, use whatever you are comfortable with. I used the triangle pattern infill setting in Cura as I thought this may be stronger but any percentage should be fine.

Update I uploaded the wrong .stl file that was 5mm thick instead of 8mm thick - the correct file is now available to download.

title: Replacement Z-Mount for use with Anet A8

description.text: Replacement single print parts for the Z mounts on either side of an Anet A8 printer. designed to be printed as pictured in the screenshot without supports. Test printed and fitted as shown in the pictures provided. 2 Versions are available to cater for those who want slotted holes for the stepper mount and those who don't. If you don't want a version with the included z stop mounting position you can just mirror the right hand side part in your chosen slicing software.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Settings above were used to print the item as shown in above pictures. I would recommend drilling the z-stop mount positions to ~1.4mm prior to fitting the endstop. Some support could be used to hold the top edges of the largest hole if you wish though I found it only caused me a tiny amount of stringing.

If someone can give me good dimensions for the A6 version of this part I could make a version suitable for that.

Design

This was mainly created through visual measurement of surface details and translation of these into an OpenSCAD file. The z-stop position is designed to replace the separate part attached to the z carriage in several z-stop modifications.

Update 04/05/2017 - No changes to feature dimensions.

  • Slotted version to move the stepper position left / right rather than forward / back.
  • Re-export of right side parts to show the front on each piece in the thumbnails.
  • Addition of a left side variant without z stop mounting position for those who don't need the z stop position and would prefer to save a little filament.

Update 08/04/2017 - New version test printed / fitted and uploaded.

Updates 04/04/2017 - Follow up on second test print. Hoping to post these revisions tomorrow after test print fitting.

  • minor tweak to positioning of sides for slightly better fit.
  • correct positions of left and right side screw slots which were out by fractions of mm.
  • change to rounded edges for slightly less filament use.
  • reduction of square hole sizes to improve strength of finished part.
  • adjustment to z stop switch holder to accommodate the edge roundings.

Updates 03/04/2017 - Follow up on my first test print.

  • repositioned side walls
  • adjusted position of z stop by 1mm
  • reduced size of top by 0.4mm
  • Enlarged screwholes in top and nut space widths
  • Removed unnecessary additional support from hole cover
  • reduced width of top interfacing parts by 0.4mm
  • moved square cutouts slightly downward to even out distance either side.
  • Split files into two sets - one with slotted holes in top for adjustment of z motor position and the other with fixed hole positions matching the original piece.

title: Cornucopia Exponential Horn iPhone Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I added a second version split out into four parts for Up! Mini owners like myself... if you have a large enough build tray, don't bother because it's just more solvent bonds, but if a Mini's all you have, give the second set of parts a try. Pro tip: print the end sections of the horn vertically, they come out much better. Pictures of four-piece build have been posted at the end.

I was inspired by brycelowes GRAMiPhone to explore the potential of passive amplification for an iPhone. I loved the idea and how fun the resulting model was, but I found that his implementation took up a lot of space and was somewhat ungainly. I might put it on a shelf but I'd never put it on the nightstand where I charge my phone. Speaking of which, that implementation didn't allow for a power cord, so when your battery is dead, the music stops.
This version uses the expansion horn as the dock itself by bending it in a coil, much like a French horn or a sousaphone.
Because the run is laid out in a spiral, I was able to give it a long enough acoustic path to tolerate a low expansion that preserves bass down to 500 Hz (exponential horns act as a high-pass filter based on the expansion coefficient you use).
I also put it on three feet so it sits stably on non-flat surfaces and you can run a charge cable under it to get to the phone in the cradle.

Having printed, assembled, and tested it, I have to say I'm impressed. At low volumes, the amplification sounds like a perceived tripling of volume. Pushing the iPhone speaker to maximum, it's much harder to tell how much it amplifies, but the difference is noticeable. I also tested it against the GRAMiPhone I printed and a wineglass, and it appears to have better bass than both.

I built the dock to accept an iPhone 5 and I left some space in there so it didn't grab. If you want more grip on the phone, to change the angle of repose (watch out for the triangle of stability of the feet!) or want to build a dock for your particular phone or phone case, I've included a STEP of the split out parts so you can push surfaces or hack in your favorite 3D modeling software. This also should allow you to adjust the splits or use different splits to print it in smaller pieces. I also have included a STEP of just the horn profile unsplit in case you want to do it as a series of rings instead of two halves or something more awesome than I could come up with (use different colors if you come up with a nice set of splits!).

This was printed on an Up! Box, and assembled with acetone for solvent bonding. I also poured acetone through the funnel to get a nice glossy surface and acoustic skin on the inside surface. I had a few challenges with undercuts on the seam, but I've since added a chamfer to the seam inside edges to get rid of the undercuts so the parts fall together. I also noticed that on the base the coil touches the tangent of the wall. On mine I cut the stitch with a razor knife, put the top and bottom together, and when I solvent-bonded it it just stuck back where it was before. Your results may vary.
I also tacked the dock onto the tangent of the horn with acetone to make it a little sturdier. The parts will assemble in whatever horn-to-phone orientation suits your fancy, just solvent-bond it in place when it's where you like it.
I'm not sure how the 7 would sound in this because of Apple's new stereo speakers, but if this were a first-world problem I had, I'd try ducting the two speakers together in the dock and feeding it into the tube, and if that didn't work I'd try splitting the horn with a vertical section down the middle and ducting one to each side of it. But that's a task for another day... (one where I can afford an iPhone 7!)

I googled the design parameters for an exponential horn profile (https://mysite.du.edu/~jcalvert/tech/speak.htm) and built a blended surface from cross-sections laid out in a spiral. Putting these sections tangent to a bottom plane resulted in a body that sat nicely on a surface. I then bent the inlet sections up into a curve to interface with a bottom of an iPhone dock, and adjusted the exit sections to start to angle upward and straighten out to give it a nice flare.

Profile of an Exponential Horn (letter tags are cross-sections in the CAD) Cross-sections laid out in the scaffold After splits and with dock attached.

comments.text:
I built it in Parametrics Creo (Pro/E), but it'd be as easy or easier to rebuild in Solidworks. If you can operate on a Pro/E file, let me know. i also could export a STEP with the curve scaffold in it so you could rebuild over it in whatever your CAD weapon of choice is. I have a feeling you'd be better off just rebuilding it than copying mine; it's always easier to fix your own stuff.
Try changing something up! I've heard from some friends they though it sounded 'tinny' because it didn't push enough bass... if you can tolerate a smaller expansion coefficient, it should provide better low-end response. Just add another coil and slow the expansion.
One other thing I did was repackage a little voice coil speaker from a Roomba into a sound chamber that would plug onto where the horn entrance was, soldered that onto a headphone jack, and that worked pretty well as a non-amplified speaker.

author: YoungBuck

title: Knife Handles cnc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These knife handles are meant as an example and to show how easy it is to make them on a desktop cnc. The quickest way to get the form of your knife is, to put them in a scanner and trace the image. I got the blade of the steak knife from a online shop where you can buy all kinds of stuff to make your own knives.

I used my desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft and a spiral-toothed 3 mm flute on 7mm oak material. To attach the handle to the blade I used brass rivets. Some soft taps with the soft hammer and my vice got the rivets fastened. After that I used a spindle sander to smooth out the forms and some oil to finish the wood.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

title: Picatinny rail for CZ75 Shadow (or other)

description.text:
I designed this picatinny rail to mount a red dot sight on my CZ75SP01 Shadow.
Printed out of PETG, as it's heat resistant and stiff enough.
I tried to use ABS but it failed as my printed dont have a heated enclosure.
I used 0.2mm layer thickness.
May be used on any other handgun with a picatinny rail under the frame, but the room for the iron sight may be inapropriate.
You'll need M5 nuts and M5x35 CHC screw.

I've tested this at the range, 100 rounds and work like a charm.

Hope you enjoy :)

This is the image of a chess king I want to make starting with a bishop 3-D file. The bishop should be enlarged by 15%; then have its spire cut off, half-way down. An elongated cone could then be added to the top forming a new chess piece.

Hello, my friend recently started a game night at his house and we made plans to play more often. I got the Oregon Trail game for game night to relive the nostalgia of dying in terrible and uncontrollable ways... you know like 90s kids used to do in 4th grade. Good Times. Anyway I decided we needed more to game night like trophies and statues, so I started with this wagon to hold the trail card deck. It is sized to fit the 60ish mm Oregon Trail cards, but could be resized for a normal deck I guess. I printed with raft and supports, though the raft may not be necessary, 10% infill body, 20% wheels, and 100% axles. My flat layers were a little saggy so I would suggest 20+% infill for the body. Either way it's a cool addition to game night, now all I need are oxen or we all die and lose the game :D.

Printer:

CTC Replicator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

The bottom needs glued to the top bit. On the bottom in the center is a triangle, I glued the "yolk" on and behind that extending forward. The wheels are also glued to the axles after they are installed and the axles spin in the holes. Sanding and other trimming may be needed for smooth glue surface or clean spinning axles.

comments.text: I have been using one of these I printed in pla and it held up reasonably well till I started printing abs. The ring for the levelling sensor started to droop, so I printed a new one in abs. turns out the droopiness was due to the edge of the extruder cooling fan square on the far side delaminating and softening. To be expected with all the heat - as it was printing the new abs one, I ended up having to zip tie the sensor over to keep it from ruining the print. The first pla one served me fairly well though and lasted a couple of months with lots of printing.

description.text:
Needed:

1 Screw M3 40mm
1 Nut M3 (To lock the screw, so that it does not turn when tightening the belt)
1 Self-locking M3 nut (It is the one used to tighten the belt, it is important that it is self-locking so that it does not unscrew with the vibrations)

-It is shorter than the original and gives you the opportunity to tighten the strap better.
-If the screw you have is round head, you can cross the piece across and block the screw with a nut, so that there is no turning when tightening the strap.
-The shaft where the bearings are placed is more separated which prevents friction with the screw

The purple design is 92m in length, holds a 22mm bearing in the center, and holds 15mm marbles, or ball bearings, in the end holes.

The orange design is 86mm in length, holds a 22mm bearing in the center, and holds 15mm marbles, or ball bearings, in the end holes.

Print flat on the plate with any filament but I would recommend something high temp as its very near be build plate and will need to take some heat.

It should hold as is but if your cable rubs against your enclosure, set the part height (Y) to 200% to give it more friction against the build plate and the cable. Shouldn't slid around then.

remixed_from.author: artec3d
remixed_from.title: Birth of Pegasus from A. Bourganov

title: Birth of Pegasus from A. Bourganov - Printable

description.text: I sliced the Birth of Pegasus model posted by artec3d for easier printing.  The original model is created from a scan of the sculpture by artist Alexander Bourganov.  There is more information on the original page.

My goal was to slice the model into as few parts as possible to enable printing without support.  I spent a while looking at the different parts of the sculpture to see how I could minimize overhangs.  Ultimately, I cut the base/pedestal into a separate piece, and then the main sculpture into two pieces.
Note that the cut is at a bit of an angle to the "face" of the sculpture.  It was necessary to reduce overhangs.
Print the three parts, scaling if desired.
Even in PLA, the the bottoms warped a little bit.  I ended up sanding down the mating faces and it helped a lot.  
Glue together.  I used super glue for my PLA prints, but you can use acetone for ABS.  I tried to align the most prominent features, such as the foot/ear.
I painted the seam to hide it.  The white paint actually matched the white PLA fairly well.  It is probably worth painting the entire thing, especially if you can't match the color.
When I sliced the model with Skeinforge, I ended up getting a few solid layers inside of the print for some reason.  It didn't affect the appearance.
I used a low infill to save time/material, since it is a large print.  This had the unintended consequence of causing the front part of the sculpture to be lower density than the back, since the narrower wings has relatively less infill.  As a result, the final print is poorly balanced and wants to tip backwards.  It does stay upright on a flat surface, but it is far from ideal.  I can't think of a better solution than increasing the infill on the front half.  I suppose you could model or drill a hole and fill it with something heavy.
Overall, it turned out great and it is one of my favorite prints.  Thanks again Artec, Alexander Bourganov and the Moscow State Museum!

description.text:
I created this because a need motor strength and a major reduction in speed  
I need to do a pully system , which has magnets , the magnets will move HO scale cars on a table , this is a test , could not find true HO scale cars what worked for my HO train set

Detatchable skeg for alpacka packraft, based on fcsfin. Serveral sizes included.
I found the 13cm version to work best with my Llama, and it really does wonders for directional stability.

Recommended 1mm layer height, 90% infill and 5 wall thickness (0.4mm nozzle), and depending of the printer maybe some over extrusion. The fin should be a bit oversize after printing and sanded to a very tight fit in the slot at the base plate.
Can be glued but I attached the base plate to the packraft with gorilla tape (slots for that added).
Cut the 5 supports on the base plate "quick release" tab after printing.

My version was printed with the cheapest chinese ABS money could buy, and all edges strengthened/saturated with superglue. Survived undamaged many summer 2016 expeditions, with both flatwater and a lot of river kayaking. Expected the "quick relesae" would knock it of when hit river bottom full speed but it just flexes away, including when hitting the bottom when going sideways.
Designed the base plate to break controlled at the upper "bulb" if overstressed (so I recommend carying a spare) but have not happened to me yet.

remixed_from.title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+

title: Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+ With Taz 5 Mount

description.text:
I combined the base clip section of the spool holder with this wonderful Raspberry Pi case so it would mount on my Taz 5 to hold my OctoPi board.

Changes from original case:

  1. I thinned out the top (slotted side). It was needlessly thick and wasted a lot of material printing it.
  2. I enlarged the SD slot. Sometimes with over extrusion, the slot was a bit tight for my liking.
  3. Added the camera cable slot.
  4. Added a channel in the top to allow the camera cable to lay flat and slide in when inserting the Pi.
  5. And the obvious, added the rail clip to the back.
  6. I undersized the outside rail fingers so its a bit tight on the Taz frame. I don't have to use the locking clip. If you want the locking clip, you can DL it from the spool holder thing.

This case can be mounted facing either way so I didn't think there would be a desire to have a mirror version. Right now I have mine clipped to the right rear rail with the Pi opening facing down (the USB and ethernet cables face down). This puts it outside the frame and behind the lower stock spool holder position as delivered from Lulzbot. If you moved your spool holder, then you will have to find another place.

To attach the camera cable, insert it from the outside in into the case and pull it out the opening (yes, you can do this with the short stock cable). Attach it to the Pi and fold it flat so it lies flat against the pi toward the SD card end. Slowly slide the Pi into the slot in the case. The camera cable should feed freely through the slot as you push the Pi in.

Here is a timelapse of the print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=znd3i78khQw

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm Layers

Infill:

30 fast honeycomb

Notes:

The only supports you should need are in the camera cable slot. If you don't put supports there, you could get some stringing across it and will not have a nice clean slot. Everything else shouldn't need support.

description.text:
Fishing rod holder for packraft.
Recommend printing a bit oversize and sanded down to a tight fit - should "click" in to place.

Diameter lessens down the tube to "jam" the fishing rod in to place, and a slot to enable fly rod reel clearance. Recommend print with ABS, 0.1mm layer height, 90% infill.

Can be glued on, I opted to use Gorilla tape but be aware when fishing in the sun, that tape will loose its grip when hot. Attach base with slot facing forward.

Now for some bragging: Used a cheap telescopic rod, a wobbler and got a 2,5Kg trout while trolling in 1m waves and strong winds. Managed to paddle to the shore with the reel screaming behind me and landed the fish - so it works :)

Awesome little charger, super handy for travel and everything. I wanted to be able to hang it off the back of my nightstand so I drew this up real quick in CAD. description.text:
Don't print this. Go get v2 instead. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2227909

I like spinners. I like multiple colors. But I only have a single extruder machine. So, this.

I wanted to make my own spinner but wanted to do something unique that I hadn't seen before and came up with the idea to do a multi part design with inlay style slots for customization.

This is my first 3D design project so feedback is much appreciated. If you print one, let me know what you think. If anyone wants the Sketchup files for remix purposes just send me a message and I will send them to you.

The caps in the photo are these : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848330
Best spinner caps I have found so far, so I didn't bother to make my own caps.

The optimal way to get the parts together is to print the inlays on a raft and press them in using the raft as a base, then break the raft off once they are fully inserted. The "inlay_double" stl file should be spaced in the proper fashion to be able to insert both inlays at once on one arm of the spinner if you are only doing a single color on one of the arms.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports best added by hand in something like Simplify3D. Be very careful removing them, especially from the spinner hole and from around the slider.

description.text:
I really liked the idea behind the printed fidget cube, and after printing and using CThig's design for a few days (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844556), I thought I could improve some aspects of it. The size should now be correct for putting into slicers, the wheel has a finger-divot instead of a post to spin, and has a circular internal 'clip' so that it doesn't fall out, the tunnel has two sizes of entry both now smoothed, the slider can be printed directly on the piece (just be extremely careful removing supports!) so there's no seam and it has a bigger place to put your finger, and I put some holes behind the switch so that two pieces of 8mm-long 1.75mm flexible filament can be put in it to give it more of a "click" feeling. Like the original, this can be completely 3D printed, but I've also include a wheel and a second cube that can be used with a 625Z bearing for the wheel.

Edit 4/17/17: If you're having trouble printing the maze section, I added some more alternatives where the maze and slider print as a separate piece from the main cube. You can still choose with or without a bearing for the wheel. In these files (Cube - No Maze, Maze and Slider), there are two 1.8mm holes in them that are for a 5mm-long piece of 1.75mm filament that you can insert as guides to glue the maze to the cube. Caution: I have not yet printed this to try it out yet -- if you do, let me know how it works!

In case you don't have 1.75mm filament on-hand, I've also included a "filament shaft" that will print the cylinder guide you'll need when gluing the parts together.

I printed it out top down with no supports. The divot came out a little stringy. I smoothed it down a bit with sand paper. I did find that, when I tried spinning it, my finger/thumb would come out and just push the face. Maybe a thicker disc with a deeper hole might be an option?
For the finger maze, I tried to add supports between the bottom of the knob and the maze. I think this was a mistake, as it ended up becoming one piece. I had to gouge it out and just made it smooth. title: The Rat
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"Hitler's fantasies sometimes shift into the gigantic"- Heinz Guderian,1943

This is a 1:100 model of the Krupp Ratte Tank.

Huge thanks to Buchnerb , http://www.thingiverse.com/Buchnerb/about, not only did he commit over 120 hours of printing time and about 6 pounds of plastic to test print but he also offered allot of advice for improving the turret design.

the 128mm turret and 20mm flak guns are from bergmans packs

Most of the details pertaining to this tank are pure speculation. Thus I took some liberties when creating the model. I designed 2 turrets. 1 ,the Ausf A, represents the planned prototype turret that would have been taken directly from the battleship Gneisenau. The second turret, Ausf B, represents a theoretical newly produced turret. I put 2 dowel holes in the hull. 1/4" diameter by 10" long(+ tolerance).This should help align the parts properly

History:
The development history of the Ratte originated with a 1941 strategic study of Soviet heavy tanks conducted by Krupp, the study also giving birth to the Panzer VIII Maus super-heavy tank.The study led to a suggestion from Krupp's director (Grotte), a special officer for submarine construction, who, on 23 June 1942, proposed to Hitler a 1,000-tonne tank which he named "Landkreuzer". It was to be armed with naval artillery and armored with 25 centimetres (10 in) of hardened steel, so heavy that only similar weapons could hope to damage it.
Hitler became enamored with Grotte's concept and ordered Krupp to begin development of it in 1942. As of December 29, 1942 a few preliminary drawings had been completed, by which time the concept had been named "Ratte" (Rat) by Hitler himself. These submitted designs went under the titles OKH Auftrag Nr. 30404 and E-30404/1.Albert Speer saw no reasonable use of the tank and canceled the project in 1943 before any prototype could be manufactured.

I've been working on this as a side project for awhile now and just recently completed it. i decided to release it as a thank you for 100 followers.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
As I wasn't happy with the print quality of my Wanhao duplicator I3 I started searching what could be wrong.
After changing and adjusting all the mechanical stuff I still got strange lines in my Benchy.

The picture of my benchy here is a picture before the mechanical adjustments, but you can clearly see the problem on the cabinet of the benchy. (diagonal lines)

The more you dial your printer in the more it get's pronounced.

So I made a drawing in onshape 2 sides are parallel to X or Y while the other are not.
The printer does not print those lines smoothly, because of missing microsteps.

If you print this and you have also those weird lines in the print, you could also suffer from missing microsteps.

description.text:
This is a simple plastic cap designed to protect 9-volt batteries from shorting out and starting fires while in storage.  Keeping unprotected 9v batteries in drawers or containers with other batteries and metal can be very dangerous.  When everything gets jumbled around, it is possible for a piece of metal to short the terminals of the battery, which will make the battery overheat and catch on fire.  This is a common cause in house fires.  
The cap simply snaps onto the terminals of the battery and protects it from short circuiting.  I printed mine on a Replicator 2 with PLA @ 0.2mm layer height.  It snaps into place perfectly and takes 5 minutes to print.
The press-fit design works best with 0.2mm layer height.

This is a 3D-Printable Time Traveling Decoration [TTD}. It will travel forward through time at a precise 1:1 ratio to it's surroundings. It is not designed to move backward or sideways through time, nor should it move forward at a rate in excess of the 1:1 calibration.

After printing, enter the Reference Time and Date on the device in the provided areas with whatever permanent marking device may be available in your time frame. This will be a handy reference point for measuring the decoration's travel through time by simply subtracting that the reference times from your current time.

Function Test: To ensure TDD is functioning properly, simply place the TTD in a specific location, and note the time. Then check again in 5 earth minutes. If the TTD is there, then the TTD is functioning properly, having traveled through time to that point 5 minutes in the future. If the device is not there, then the likely causes are: 1: It failed to move through time and is therefore irrevocably lost. 2: It skipped forward in time, and may appear at some future point. 3: Someone stole it!

Small errors in printing should not negatively impact performance.

Enjoy you time-travels, use the TTD for good and not evil, and beware of murlocks!

description.text: Presenting the remix of the remix. This is a mounting clip for an Azteeg X3 and designed to slot into the center channel of an OpenBeam extrusion. The center hole is sized for an M3 x 8mm cap head screw. Secure with a DIN934 M3 nut inserted into the extrusion slot. The is a modification of blah_59's design @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:150566, originally sourced from Steve Graber. The design now has a slightly wider central screw hole, and slimmed down channel block based on test print results, which should make it easier to install. If you downloaded this design prior to 1/13, you do not have the latest version.

ANGLE GRIPPER
This gripper is modeled off my favorite gripper, PHD's GRB's angle gripper. The gripper arms rotate 90 degrees by pushing/pulling the center rod. The center rod has a pivot pin connected to each finger so when you push the rod it rotates the fingers.

You dont get as much clamp force with this type of gripper as a traditional parallel jaw gripper but in some applications it could save an axis of moment and its very fast.

What is hollow shaft stepper motor?
Hollow shaft stepper motor is stepper motor with hollow shaft or bore on the shaft, the hollow shaft can be divided into 3 types according to RobotDigg (http://www.robotdigg.com/)
http://www.robotdigg.com/news/35/
http://www.robotdigg.com/news/90

  1. Coarse bore hollow shaft stepper motor
    A hollow shaft stepper motor with coarse or relatively rough machined bore is used for Air, Beam or Cables to be through.
    Nema8,
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/43
    Nema11,
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/85/
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/798/
    Nema17
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/21/
    Typical applications
    SMC Motor for Pick and Place Machine, OpenPnP
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/675/
    http://openpnp.org/hardware/
    Robotics, Dynamic Robotic or Mobile Scanner
    http://rhoeby.com/video/

  2. Screw hollow shaft stepper motor
    Hollow shaft stepper motor with screw for lead screw, known as Non-captive Linear Stepper. When comes to choose, you'd better have a look on the pitch and lead.
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/86/

  3. Precise bore hollow shaft stepper motor
    Precise bore compared with coarse bore, it's the precision of the hollow shaft (no screw inside). Precise bore hollow shaft stepper motor is used the most for Bespoke Ball Screws. You are Not decided how long and which ball screw to be used while designing but you want to have a linear stepper to do the job. Then you only have to do the custom ball screw to fix the hollow shaft at your side or local.
    Compared with stepper motor, coupling and ball screw combination, the precise bore hollow shaft stepper motor for bespoke ball screw is more reliable, neat, space saving and precise for automation applications because you can take the hollow shaft as a longer coupling which can ensure the concentricity.
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/645/
    http://www.robotdigg.com/product/646/

description.text:
All credit to AgentOrin, who was inspired by a well known Nerf Modder on youtube.

I used Meshmixer to stitch together the multiple shells that were giving Cura and Slic3r fits. I also split the hopper and lid into separate files to ease placement on smaller print beds.

Supports are a must for this print. To get it to stick to my masking tape print bed, i had to wipe the tape down with isopropyl alcohol. I haven't had to do this with other prints.

I'd prefer to extend the outer shell of the hopper down to the print bed, at a angle that will not require support. But, that will need to wait until i pick up 3d modeling.

Update 1: Top cover added, split in 1/2 for small print beds. Gluing the two halves together isn't required, they hold in place decently. Matchbox red PLA is a reasonable match for the red blaster.

description.text: Based on some other similar adjustable Z endstops. For M3 screws.

print_settings.Notes:: I say print at 100% infill, but I really just print enough top and bottom layers that there is no infill at all, same thing. Modify the overall Z height and infill if you think it's appropriate for the design you're testing.

description.text:
This is a plate designed to print every hole from 2.0mm to 8.9mm in 0.1mm increments.

Pictured are a 3D printed version (pink) and an acrylic laser cut version (black).

The cutout orientation corner is the top left. Holes increase from 2mm to 8mm across, and increase from +0.0mm to +0.9mm down.

This is intended to test clearance for metric screws, so you know how accurate your printer/cutter is at making various size holes, and so you can test with real screws you already own and design your part so the screws fit.

Some might consider this better than say designing a 3mm hole, having it print at 2.5mm, and drilling the hole out to fit an M3 screw.

Note that you aren't supposed to print/drill/cut holes exactly to the thread size they hold. Look up "metric thread clearance" on Google and you'll see the recommended size for a metric thread is always slightly larger than the actual thread.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm to 0.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I say print at 100% infill, but I really just print enough top and bottom layers that there is no infill at all, same thing. Modify the overall Z height and infill if you think it's appropriate for the design you're testing.

OpenSCAD file is included so you can modify as desired.

Requires scad-utils from https://github.com/openscad/scad-utils

It's a 2D design extruded vertically so you can also export as a DXF for laser cutting.

It's mostly scripted with variables so you could probably make this into a Customizer with minimal effort.

License is CC-BY-SA so please share your remixes for the benefit others.

The most difficult part of this design was using in-context edits to make sure the tongues and grooves mated properly without creating a feedback loop of references.
I had some time to waste so I made this. Since I only use Tinkercad this took me a while to make but it turned out great. This uses a standard 608 ball bearing. Have fun with making this!

I use a Black and Decker string trimmer for my yard. The auto-feed spools (AF-100) work really well at always keeping the right amount of string out. They swap in and out quickly when you run out of string. New spools are kind of expensive, so this jig lets you quickly re-spool on new string in a jiffy!

Video of the jig in use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lg-0gDuBrSw

The print doesn't require any overhangs. The largest dimension is 4", so most printers ought to be able to tackle it. The winder requires a 1/4 inch bolt and nut to make it drill compatible.

UPDATE: Added a power winder that should be compatible with an M6 Bolt.

author: EthanNewhouse

description.text:
This print is designed to demonstrate conductive filament (Conductive PLA from
proto-pasta.com).

Using a single extruder 3d printer, half-way through the print the conductive PLA is swapped in allowing the bus bars to be printed that connect the inserted batteries into a circuit. A soldering iron can be used to heat up the LED's leads and melt them into the positive a nd negative conductive terminals as shown.

Insert AAA batteries in alternating fashion. The '+' (positive) side bump goes towards terminal ends with a thinner spring member and the '-' (negative) side goes towards the thicker terminals.

V4 - finally happy with this version, abandoned the LED lead holes and got enough spring in the positive terminal design to hold all batteries securely
V3 - made holes for LED leads even larger, still too small, adjusted terminals, still a poor fit, working on another terminal design for the positive terminal
V2 - updated adding a gap between terminals to allow for batteries of slightly different lengths to be better accommodated.

author: SgtMunger

description.text: Need to inflate twisting balloons to twist into Dogs, Cats, and Giraffes?  Don't have a special pump?  No problem.  Screw this attachment onto a common bicycle pump and inflate.

1) Print
2) Sand burs as needed, the conical portion needs to be fairly smooth. Always sand it circumferentially and never axially so it seals well.
3) Screw or otherwise insert into pump. There are no threads on the adapter, but it can be thread formed (you may need to clamp it in a vise).
4) Slide a balloon onto the adapter as far as it will go, and then a little farther.
5) Inflate (Remember NOT to fully inflate or it will pop when you try to twist it).

description.text:
I made this insert out of frustration after the only screwdrivers I had would fall right through the rings on pegboard screwdriver holders and get stuck. These inserts hold either 1 screwdriver in the middle, or two smaller ones side by side in the same ring. The small holes have a diameter of 0.2 inches, and the large center hole has a 0.32 inch diameter. The inserts fit into standard circular pegboard screwdriver holders with ~3/4" rings. A small bump on the bottom holds the insert in place so it doesn't pull out.

Video of how useful it is at: youtube.com/watch?v=7LoXfJKE7hg

I'm sharing this for your own use. If you want to sell this commercially, please contact me first.

remixed_from.author: strex
remixed_from.title: Wire Clips - Prusa i3 (3DP-11-ATL) and others

title: LED Clips - Prusa i3 (3DP-11-ATL) and others

description.text:
After much trial and error, and several revisions I finally got these little guys working great. The clip attaches securely to the (20mm) frame of the Prusa i3 (3DP-11-ATL), and the opposite side securely holds a 10mm LED strip! Once secured the angle of the LEDs is 23.5 degrees, which ended up being just right for almost every print I could throw at it.

To install, first clip it to the inside of the printer frame (facing the bed), on all 3 sides, hold up your LED strip to test for length, and cut to size. Then starting at one end, put the LED stip into one side of the clip, then the other side. It's a snug fit so you might have to use a little force, a fingernail, or plastic pry tool might help (but a screwdriver might damage the strip). Work your way around, one by one, until finished.

Edit: The "LED Clip Final stl" is for mounting the LED strip on the outside of the frame. The "LED Clip Inner Final stl" is for mounting the LED stip on the inside of the frame, this is useful for places like where the control board and power supply mount to the frame (on the 3DP-11-ATL), and the outside clip wouldn't work. These inner clips are designed to be a tight fit, and twist into place, when installing them, take note of the 45 degree angle on the shaft, as the clip will only turn in the direction of the angle. Not the other direction. If you print it out, and give it a try, you'll see what I'm talking about.

Enjoy!

Many printers have a back plate that can be unscrewed and reversed to reveal a shiny back plate. This is a perfect spot to add a little customization to your printer. I recommend a dab of super glue. (Mine looks a bit off because I used a gluestick. I put a dab off super glue on and it looks right in line.) Also important to note: I added a gear in order to make everything one solid piece.

There are two files for single extruding printers. These files are those with the sign already labeled. One is a generic label and the other has the text offset so you can add your name with a simple 3D modeling program (Tinkercad (https://www.tinkercad.com) or 3D builder App work fine for adding text). The font is sans.

I included the text and gears as separate files so the splicing should be simple. I recommend Using Tinkercad https://www.tinkercad.com or 3D builder to add your name and personalize it. Otherwise you can center the text onto the other file to make a generic label

Square tiles with hex holes and hollow bottom!
A thousand and one uses!
Use as a soap dish,
or a coaster for the coffee table,
or assemble a few together (set "linkable" to true) to make a larger mat

The hollow bottom allows small "stuff" (i.e. kitty litter, water, air) to fall through holes and accumulate underneath, while keeping larger "things" (i.e. cats, bars of soap, beverage containers) from falling through.
You could adjust the size to fit your gutters and keep "things" (i.e. leaves) out while letting "stuff" (i.e. rainwater) pass through.
Whatever kinds of "stuff" and "things" you may have, you're sure to find a way to use these tiles to improve the way your "stuff" and "things" behave and/or interact.

My original intent was to make a modular cat litter control mat, to be placed in front of the cat's litter box. The idea was inspired by an overpriced (in my opinion) commercial kitty litter mat with hexagonal holes in the top layer and a second layer to catch the litter. I don't want to pay $30 for a litter mat, so I decided I could print something that functions similarly. Since the printer isn't big enough to make a 24x36 inch mat, I decided to make tiles. Hopefully the litter will fall through and then the tiles can occasionally be lifted to vacuum it up.

Parameters:
Size: Overall height and width (tiles are square, height and width is always equal)
Height: Overall height of the tile
Thick: Thickness of the top deck of the tile
CornerRadius: radius of the corners, use 0 for square corners.
Linkable: if true (or 1), holes are added along the edges to allow linking tiles together. (Link pieces have not been designed yet, but that should only take a few minutes once I get around to it)

title: Helmet mount for Contour video cameras

description.text:
I didn't think the mounts that came with my Contour Roam were trustworthy so I quickly designed this one. It's got a bit of a curve on the mounting surface to match the side of a helmet.
Includes a detent bump with an integral springy rail behind it so the camera snaps into place.
This should be in pretty good shape as is but I have not ridden with it yet.

Print, clip your camera to it, decide where on your helmet to mount the camera. Apply double sided foam tape to the mounting surface and use a zip tie to secure through helmet vents. Note that there is a bump with a spring detent behind it along the rails - this goes toward the FRONT of the camera (at least it does on the Roam) to hold the camera in place.
The SCAD file is there if you need to tweak this for your situation.

comments.text:
Hello!
Just letting you know I used your model to potentially create something!
Thanks for creating it!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:893894
comments.author: swordfish

comments.text: I made one of these and there is one problem area. Its a big enough issue to cause this mount to be unusable in actual use. Here is the issue I found. The top rail of the T portion is not thick enough and does not fit snugly into the camera. I tried this one three different Contour cameras and on three different waterproof housings. The mounts are so loose that not only does the camera rock in place, but the mount does not snap in like the genuine Contour mounts. On the waterproof cases, it will be hard to fix because of the way Contour built them. Without shortening the distance from the base to the bottom of the rail as well as making the nub slightly larger the mount simply falls out of the waterproof housing. It will be a hard balance to get it to fit snug in the housing and not too tight on the camera. Either way with how loose these fit the camera vibrates in place causing a lot of oscillations in the recorded video. It is too much to post-process out.
comments.author: WheresWaldo

comments.text: Interesting.  It worked well for me.  I've found, however, that there is a pretty significant variation in dimension from one slicing software to another when it comes to printing things with tight tolerances.

Still mine does not fit the Waterproof housing well either, although its a real snug fit in the cameras. In the Waterproof housing there is just too much play. Don't really understand why Contour built the housings that way.

author: GerryPB

title: Alfa Romeo Giulia Glove Box Latch

description.text:
Replacement finger thing for the Giulia glove box latch.

These cars have an awful design for the glove box latch. They clip this plastic part on to actuate the latch instead of just casting a little metal finger on the lock cylinder for some reason.

Buddy picked up a Quadrifoglio and made the mistake of trying to put the owners manual in the glove box. Well, it don't fit, and here we are.

If you ran into the same, it is an easy fix.
Open the latch and you will see 2 of the tabs that hold it on. If you look closely, you can see the 3rd hiding on the other side of the lock cylinder. I'd poke at the 3rd one if you can, pops the latch right out.

Now you should see the finger that opens it, just slide it sideways and it will open.

If you pulled the lever so far that it wont go back in, you will need to push the hinge pin out to get it back where it needs to be. It's easy and slides right out.

If you look at the spring on it, it should be down on the side of the lock cylinder. If it is caught on the end near where this stl clips on, it will give it a sort of detent action in the closed and open positions. Doesn't really seem like a problem either way.

My attempt to fix some slicing weirdness with the no support version by Gelb153. I used the updated V2 eggbot frame posted by jjrobots which has improved electronics holes and slightly different tailstock features.

SS3d had issues slicing the model so I added a model sent through MakeItPrintable; it is called EggBot_MainFrame_V2_Easy_Print_Repair. This slices well in S3D but has the artifact of part of the bottom is no longer hollowed out. Should not affect function and may improve overall print time...

I noticed from printing and the model that the electronics holder still needs supports to print correctly...

Feedback welcome!

3d Modeling edit

DesignSpark Mechanical (freeware!) - surprisingly was easier to convert the STL and add components than in SolidWorks 17!

So I had to run it through makeprintable.com to get the STL to slice right. It's a nice service with a free option as long as you don't need to do more than 3 repairs per month.

title: cbd-3d MOSFET enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since the controller board that comes with the Tevo Tarantula is apparently not designed to handle the current necessary for heating the bed to print ABS without catching fire, a MOSFET expansion board is needed. Being a technician, I could have easily built one, but when you can get one on Amazon for eleven bucks - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MY50JL3 - why bother? It does need an enclosure, however.

This case is designed to be used with the MOSFET controller boards marked "www.cbd-3d.com V1.3". A 30mm fan is mounted behind the heatsink to aid in cooling. I suggest orienting the fan so that air is pulled through the box and out the fan, thereby sucking heat out while bringing cool air in the front grill. The control wires are brought out the front through the horizontal slit.

While designing the box, I modeled the board itself just for the hell of it. I haven't printed the board model, but I am including it in case you want to. If you do decide to print the model, please post photos so we can see how it comes out.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Make sure that the lid is oriented upside down to eliminate the need for supports. Support may be needed for the model of the board, though, since the MOSFET would print in mid-air otherwise.

This was the third box I printed. On the first try, the mounting holes for the board didn't line up - I forgot to measure twice, print once. On the second go round, I didn't take into account the length of the fan's mounting bolts/nuts. Finally, on the third try, I got it right. Only on the last print, the center piece of the fan opening got knocked over during the print! If you look closely at the rear of the box, you can see where I printed the insert separately and glued it in place. And let me tell you... this was CLOSE. I had just a little over a couple of feet of filament left when this case completed. That was too close for comfort!

title: Tweaked HeatSync Labs Egg Decorating Robot

description.text:
FIrmware: Use https://github.com/nebarnix/EggDuinoNano

This remix includes upgraded O-ring / Nerf Dart holders for the idler and the egg axis. I found that the O-rings didn't work, but that the Nerf holders did.

It also contains a printable bolt for the idler (you must remove the head, then use an M3 screw to reattach after assembly)

The PCB holder fits an Arduino nano GRBL CNC board.

It also contains thumbwheels for the pen arm height bolt (M4) and the marker holder bolt (M3). Use a drill press or an arbor press to push the screws into the thumbwheel (works best if printed out of PETg or ABS due to their softness).

The distal pen holders have not been changed, this size just works for this build. Use the original thing's openscad script to generate the models if you need to customize.

description.text:
Bed Leveling Calibration Piece (X shaped)  
(probably there are tons of other such objects around)

I just finished a Nerf gun conversion and needed a brace to hold it up. I call it my angry monster support. Designed in Tinkercad and printed with a Printrbot with PLA. I added a strip of leather to hold it snug.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 mm

Infill:

20%

I wanted a simple, rugged keychain case to carry around a Wemos D1 Mini board. So after a Saturday afternoon of playing in TinkerCAD and test printing, I finally came up with this.

It's nothing fancy. It has moderate clearance around the USB receptacle and the reset button can be pressed with something like a pen.

I included two versions... the solid version and the vented version. You can use either base with either cap so print whatever you want.

UPDATE 2017-09-27:
I have uploaded a new version of the design. This one includes a stronger connector and has the wifi logo embedded in the base and the cap.
